article:
'Trans-splicing' is a special form of RNA processing in eukaryotes where exons
from two different primary RNA transcripts are joined end to end and ligated.

In contrast "normal" (''cis''-)splicing processes a single molecule. That is,
trans-splicing results in an RNA transcript that came from multiple RNA
polymerases on the genome. This phenomenon can be exploited for molecular
therapy to address mutated gene products.

Trans-splicing can be the mechanism behind certain oncogenic fusion
transcripts.

Trans-splicing is used by certain microbial organisms, notably protozoa of the
Kinetoplastae class to produce variable surface antigens and change from one
life stage to another.
